Ask HN: Why don't we have 3 day weekends yet?
text:
After covid, and the temporary transition to remote (for some), it seem that switching from 5 days to 4 days would be an arbitrary decision, with very little real impact. (Of course I'm referring to jobs done in typical 5 day week).

For those who say it would lead to a decrease in productivity. Well that is only relative to the 5 day week. And the 5 day week, only exist because of some archaic reasons. It is not some law ingrained in the universe.

And beyond that we can see that increases of productivity has not led to increase of leisure time, maybe the opposite.

And we know many people who work barely a fraction of the week, yet need to maintain this kind of presenteeism. It seems absurd. Will we be trapped in this irrational mindset forever, or just until a certain generations dies out?

Ask HN: How to find non-remote office or hybrid jobs?
text:
Most job search engines have added "remote friendly" or "remote only" options to filter positions by, but I haven't found anywhere that makes it easy to find jobs that are specifically in person, or at least hybrid. I'm just getting out of a remote job, and I'm hoping for my next one to have a strong in-person component to it.

As an aside, I know this is a hot button issue for a lot of folks, but I'd prefer this thread not devolve into arguing over the merits of remote vs office. Not trying to make a statement here, just trying to see if there's a tool to help me find what I want!

Ask HN: How do you get your suspended Twitter account reinstated?
text:
Here is a background

I have been running https://www.pythonweekly.com/ newsletter for the last 11 years. There is also an active Twitter account @PythonWeekly for it where I have been tweeting about Python related content. The Twitter account is 11 years old with 55k+ followers and 14k+ tweets over the years. All of a sudden, on Monday, Twitter suspended @PythonWeekly account and the reason given via email is "Violating our rules against evading permanent suspension." I really don't know how this reason applies in this case. We never had any issues whatsoever before. I immediately appealed via their standard process and also I followed up again, but haven't heard back yet.

Has anyone here experienced a similar issue? If so, were you able to get your account reinstated?

I am sure there are Twitter employees who frequent HN and if someone there can help get the account reinstated, I will highly appreciate it.

Show HN: I wrote a book about remodeling old houses
text:
Heya HN!

Over the summer I took a much needed break from working on software all day (I'm a designer who codes) and wrote a book about remodeling old houses instead.

Over the last 8 years or so I've found working with my hands – building things, flipping houses, learning new skills – to be incredibly fulfilling. There's just something about ending your day physically tired vs mentally tired that's just so different. In 2020 in particular I decided renovate our primary bath top to bottom, learning a ton about tiling, plumbing, electrical, and so much more.

After three massive house projects – and a ton of mistakes – I decided to write down everything I've learned about remodeling a house.

If you've ever wanted to try some DIY projects around the house or make bigger changes to your space you might enjoy the book.

I'd love to know what you think or hear about your projects!

Has anyone learnt enough coding and CS from online courses to change careers?
text:
I am talking about someone who comes from a seemingly unrelated field, gets fascinated by CS or programming. Then decides to learn as much CS and programming as possible out of curiousity. Uses books and publicly available university course materials (not random dumbed down MOOCs) to build up the programming and problem solving skills and then goes to industry or grad school or some research lab.

If anyone has done that, which courses and books worked wonders for you? For building coding skills as well as learning CS as CS is not programming. But programming helps in understanding CS better.
